After more than a year, I‚Äôm glad the U.S. Senate finally confirmed John Ryder to serve on the @TVAnews‚Äô Board of Directors. John is a respected leader in Shelby County and in our state.  https://www.alexander.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/pressreleases?ID=BC72E388-0AD3-4918-8B03-F8C48B72C33D¬†‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/4i0tnZ0XI4
‚Ä¶and determine whether we can both build the 234 miles of border wall that the president requested and avoid this dangerous precedent.
It may be a couple of weeks before the Senate votes on a resolution regarding the national emergency declaration so there is time for the president‚Äôs lawyers to take another look‚Ä¶

It avoids taking money for military construction projects specifically approved by Congress such as military barracks and hospitals. And it also avoids months or years of litigation, which could make it unlikely the full 234 miles are ever built.
Using authority already approved by Congress avoids the constitutional crisis of separation of powers. It avoids establishing a dangerous precedent, which could be misused by subsequent presidents.

There is a way the president can avoid this dangerous precedent completely: he can use the congressional funding authority he already has to build the 234 miles of wall that he asked Congress to approve in his January 6 letter to the Senate.

The late Justice Antonin Scalia said, ‚Äúgenius of the American constitutional system is the dispersal of power. Once power is centralized in one person, or one part of government, the Bill of Rights is just words of paper.‚Äù
Separation of those powers is a crucial constitutional imperative that goes to the heart of our freedom.
The Constitution gave that responsibility exclusively to a Congress elected by the people, and every one of us United States senators has sworn an oath to support that Constitution.
After an American revolution against a king, our founders chose not to create a chief executive who could tax the people and spend their money any way he chose.
There is no limit to the imagination of what the next leftwing president could do to harm our country with this precedent.

If President Trump can build a wall when Congress has refused to provide the funding, then the next president can declare a national emergency and tear the wall down or declare a climate change emergency and stop oil exports and offshore drilling.
There has never been an instance where a president has asked for funding, Congress refused it, and the president then used the National Emergencies Act to justify spending the money anyway.

I support what the president wants to do on border security, but not the way he has been advised to do it.

Today, I hope to hear about how close are we to having a non-addictive painkiller, and how doctors and nurses can better treat people with pain.

Now that we have started to turn the train around and head in a different direction on the use of opioids, everyone ‚Äì doctors, nurses, insurers, and patients ‚Äì will need to think about the different ways we should treat and manage pain.

And fourth, the new law requires the Secretary of @HHSGov to report the impact on pain patients that Federal and State laws and regulations that limit the length, quantity, or dosage of opioid prescriptions.

Second, we included provisions to encourage new pain management strategies, such as physical therapy. Third, the new law requires experts to study chronic pain and report to the Director of the @NIH how patients can better manage their pain.

First ‚Äì We gave the @NIH more flexibility and authority to spur research and development of new non-addictive painkillers. We have backed up those new authorities with substantial funding ‚Äì most recently $500 million to help the NIH find a new non-addictive painkiller.
We also took steps to ensure our new law wouldn‚Äôt make life harder for patients with pain, but now we need to take the next step to try to find new ways to help them.
Last year, Congress passed comprehensive opioid legislation to combat this crisis, which @POTUS called ‚Äúthe single largest bill to combat a drug crisis in the history of our country.‚Äù
More than 70,000 Americans died from drug overdoses last year, including prescription opioids, making it the biggest public health crisis in our country.
These Americans need more effective ways than opioids or other addictive painkillers to manage pain. Opioids, which are commonly used to treat pain, can lead to addiction and overdose.
We are holding this hearing to better understand the causes of pain, how we can improve care for patients with pain, and where we are on developing new medicines and ways to treat pain.
But on the theory that every action has an unintended consequence, we want to make sure that as we deal with the opioid crisis, we keep in mind those people that are hurting.
Here is the reality: we are engaged in a massive effort to make dramatic reductions in the supply and use of opioids ‚Äì the most effective painkiller we have.

A new report released in 2018, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, says that about 50 million Americans have chronic pain, and nearly 20 million of those Americans have high-impact chronic pain.

Dan‚Äôs wife is one out of 100 million Americans who, according to a 2011 report by what was then the Institute of Medicine, now the National Academy of Medicine, are living with some pain‚Äîthat is about 30 percent of Americans. 25 million of those have moderate or severe pain.
Dan wrote, ‚ÄúShe is not an abuser, and is doing everything right. Now it‚Äôs harder for her to get the medicine she needs.‚Äù

Dan, a constituent of mine who lives in Maryville, recently wrote me on @facebook about his wife, who has a rare disease that causes her chronic pain. Dan is concerned because it has become more difficult for her to access painkillers.

I‚Äôm about to chair the Senate health committee‚Äôs hearing on how we can better understand the causes of pain, improve care for patients with pain, and where we are on developing new medicines and ways to treat pain during the opioid crisis. Watch here:  https://www.help.senate.gov/hearings/managing-pain-during-the-opioid-crisis¬†‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/rYzrfhAbkY

Today, I am interested in hearing more about specific recommendations to improve access to affordable primary care.

And, employers are increasingly taking an active role in their employees‚Äô health and in the cost of health care, like employing a doctor on-site so employees don‚Äôt have to take time off of work to see a primary care doctor.

There are other ways to lower health care costs through expanded access to primary care. Another is community health centers, which we talked about at our last hearing and that are where 27 million Americans go for their primary care.

And, while the data may be incomprehensible today, it is a ripe opportunity for innovation from private companies to arrange the data so primary care doctors can help their patients can have better outcomes and better experiences at lower costs.

I believe we can empower primary care doctors, nurse practitioners, and physicians assistants to go even a step further. At our 4th hearing, we heard about how patients have no idea how much a particular treatment or test will end up costing.

Dr. Adam Boehler, who leads the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation, recently told me that primary care is only 3-7 percent of health care spending, but affects as much as half of all health care spending.
Dr. Gross‚Äô practice is one of about a thousand similar clinics in the United States and is a good example of how a primary care doctor can help reduce costs.

In 2010, Dr. Gross created one of the first Direct Primary Care practices. Instead of working with insurance companies and government programs, Dr. Gross‚Äô patients pay him a flat monthly fee directly.

.@drleegross, of Florida, testified last year at this committee‚Äôs fifth hearing on the cost of health care that too many government mandates and insurance companies were getting between doctors and patients and making primary care more expensive than it needed to be.

I‚Äôm about to chair the Senate health committee‚Äôs hearing to learn how primary care can play a role in lowering health care costs and improving outcomes, and explore innovative ways to improve access to affordable primary care. Watch live here:  https://www.help.senate.gov/hearings/how-primary-care-affects-health-care-costs-and-outcomes¬†‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/TpyxROeNye

TUNE-IN at about 4:45 PM ET today ‚Äì I‚Äôll be talking on the Senate floor about my top three priorities for updating the Higher Education Act. Watch live here:  http://floor.senate.gov/MediaPlayer.php?view_id=2&event_id=2785¬†‚Ä¶ #MakingCollegeWorthIt #HigherEd

It is our responsibility to take whatever steps we can to help students afford college and make sure that the degrees they earn are worth the time and money they pay for them. #MakingCollegeWorthIt pic.twitter.com/vwhLbGluFE

In my conversations with Democrat and Republican senators, I have found a remarkable degree of bipartisan consensus about the directions we should take to make college affordable and make students‚Äô degrees worth their time and money.
This year, I have met with Ranking Democrat Senator @PattyMurray and nine other committee members to discuss compiling these ideas into a single piece of legislation.

During the last four years, the Senate education committee has held 27 hearings on the Higher Education Act.  These hearings have resulted in a number of bipartisan proposals that make college more affordable and worth students‚Äô time and money.

Third, I am proposing a new accountability system based upon whether borrowers are actually repaying their student loans. This should lower tuition for some programs, or even discourage schools from offering programs that are not worth it to students.

This plan makes sure if there was no money earned, there would be no money owed, and that would not reflect negatively on a borrower‚Äôs credit. The other option would be a 10-year payment plan, with equal monthly payments, similar to a 10-year mortgage.

The option I believe most borrowers would choose is a repayment plan based on a borrower‚Äôs income, which would never require the borrower to make payments of more than ten percent of his or her discretionary income.

Second, a new way to repay student loans: We should scrap the current system of nine different ways to repay federal student loans. It should be replaced with two options, both of which would automatically deduct payments from your paycheck.
First, simplify the #FAFSA: We can cut the dreaded Free Application for Federal Student Aid from 108 questions to no more than two dozen.
Today, I have three proposals to help make the answer to all four of those questions YES.

And from administrators as well‚Äîcan‚Äôt you do something about the jungle of red tape that makes it so hard to apply for federal financial aid, to pay back student loans and that wastes money on overhead that could instead be spent on students?
The questions I hear most often about college are: Can I afford it? Is it worth it? And can you make applying for financial aid and repaying student loans simpler?
The U.S. has most of the best colleges in the world, but also the most graduates paying off college debt. Roughly 40 million borrowers owe $1.5 trillion in collective student loan debt.

A college graduate paying more than $1000 per month on student loans recently wrote, ‚ÄúI was told to chase down a bachelor‚Äôs degree by any means necessary. But no one mentions just how expensive and soul-crushing the debt will be.‚Äù
